message.content: Search the /home/ryan/erdos/conjectures/ directory for lean files that use SimpleGraph. Find 2-3 examples and return their full contents. Focus on files that deal with graph concepts like diameter, edges, vertices. Use Grep to search for "SimpleGraph" or "diameter" or "Graph" in the conjectures directory, then read the most relevant files.

1â†’import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Basic
     2â†’import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Coloring
     3â†’import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Walks.Basic
     4â†’import Mathlib.SetTheory.Cardinal.Aleph
     5â†’
     6â†’open SimpleGraph Cardinal
     7â†’
     8â†’universe u
     9â†’
    10â†’noncomputable section
    11â†’
    12â†’/-!
    13â†’# ErdÅ‘s Problem #740
    14â†’
    15â†’Let ğ”ª be an infinite cardinal and G be a graph with chromatic number ğ”ª.
    16â†’Let r â‰¥ 1. Must G contain a subgraph of chromatic number ğ”ª which does not
    17â†’contain any odd cycle of length â‰¤ r?
    18â†’
    19â†’A question of ErdÅ‘s and Hajnal [Er69b][Er71,p.100][Er81][Er95d].
    20â†’RÃ¶dl proved this is true if ğ”ª = â„µâ‚€ and r = 3 (see [108] for the finitary
    21â†’version).
    22â†’
    23â†’More generally, ErdÅ‘s and Hajnal asked whether for every cardinal ğ”ª and
    24â†’integer r, there exists f_r(ğ”ª) such that every graph with chromatic number
    25â†’â‰¥ f_r(ğ”ª) contains a subgraph with chromatic number ğ”ª with no odd cycle
    26â†’of length â‰¤ r.
    27â†’
    28â†’https://www.erdosproblems.com/740
    29â†’-/
    30â†’
    31â†’/-- The cardinal chromatic number of a graph: the infimum of cardinals Îº
    32â†’    for which G admits a proper Îº-coloring. -/
    33â†’noncomputable def SimpleGraph.cardChromaticNumber {V : Type u}
    34â†’    (G : SimpleGraph V) : Cardinal.{u} :=
    35â†’  sInf {Îº : Cardinal.{u} | âˆƒ (Î± : Type u), #Î± = Îº âˆ§ Nonempty (G.Coloring Î±)}
    36â†’
    37â†’/--
    38â†’ErdÅ‘s Problem #740 [Er69b][Er71][Er81][Er95d]:
    39â†’
    40â†’If G is a graph with infinite chromatic number ğ”ª, then for every r â‰¥ 1,
    41â†’G contains a subgraph with chromatic number ğ”ª that has no odd cycle of
    42â†’length â‰¤ r.
    43â†’
    44â†’A question of ErdÅ‘s and Hajnal. RÃ¶dl proved the case ğ”ª = â„µâ‚€, r = 3.
    45â†’-/
    46â†’theorem erdos_problem_740 {V : Type u} (G : SimpleGraph V)
    47â†’    (ğ”ª : Cardinal.{u}) (hğ”ª_inf : â„µâ‚€ â‰¤ ğ”ª)
    48â†’    (hÏ‡ : G.cardChromaticNumber = ğ”ª) (r : â„•) (hr : 1 â‰¤ r) :
    49â†’    âˆƒ (W : Type u) (H : SimpleGraph W),
    50â†’      H.cardChromaticNumber = ğ”ª âˆ§
    51â†’      (âˆƒ f : W â†’ V, Function.Injective f âˆ§ âˆ€ a b, H.Adj a b â†’ G.Adj (f a) (f b)) âˆ§
    52â†’      (âˆ€ (w : W) (p : H.Walk w w), p.IsCycle â†’ Odd p.length â†’ r < p.length) :=
    53â†’  sorry
    54â†’
    55â†’end
    56â†’

1â†’import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Basic
     2â†’import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Coloring
     3â†’import Mathlib.SetTheory.Cardinal.Aleph
     4â†’
     5â†’open SimpleGraph Cardinal
     6â†’
     7â†’universe u
     8â†’
     9â†’noncomputable section
    10â†’
    11â†’/-!
    12â†’# ErdÅ‘s Problem #739
    13â†’
    14â†’Let ğ”ª be an infinite cardinal and G be a graph with chromatic number ğ”ª.
    15â†’Is it true that, for every infinite cardinal ğ”« < ğ”ª, there exists a subgraph
    16â†’of G with chromatic number ğ”«?
    17â†’
    18â†’A question of Galvin [Ga73], who proved this is true with ğ”ª = â„µâ‚€.
    19â†’KomjÃ¡th [Ko88b] proved it is consistent that the answer is no
    20â†’(with ğ”ª = â„µâ‚‚ and ğ”« = â„µâ‚). Shelah [Sh90] proved that assuming V = L,
    21â†’the answer is yes with ğ”ª = â„µâ‚‚ and ğ”« = â„µâ‚.
    22â†’
    23â†’https://www.erdosproblems.com/739
    24â†’-/
    25â†’
    26â†’/-- The cardinal chromatic number of a graph: the infimum of cardinals Îº
    27â†’    for which G admits a proper Îº-coloring. -/
    28â†’noncomputable def SimpleGraph.cardChromaticNumber {V : Type u}
    29â†’    (G : SimpleGraph V) : Cardinal.{u} :=
    30â†’  sInf {Îº : Cardinal.{u} | âˆƒ (Î± : Type u), #Î± = Îº âˆ§ Nonempty (G.Coloring Î±)}
    31â†’
    32â†’/--
    33â†’ErdÅ‘s Problem #739 [Er81]:
    34â†’
    35â†’If G is a graph with infinite chromatic number ğ”ª, then for every infinite
    36â†’cardinal ğ”« < ğ”ª, there is a subgraph of G with chromatic number ğ”«.
    37â†’
    38â†’A question of Galvin, who proved the case ğ”ª = â„µâ‚€. This is not provable
    39â†’in ZFC: KomjÃ¡th showed it is consistent that the answer is no.
    40â†’-/
    41â†’theorem erdos_problem_739 {V : Type u} (G : SimpleGraph V)
    42â†’    (ğ”ª : Cardinal.{u}) (hğ”ª_inf : â„µâ‚€ â‰¤ ğ”ª)
    43â†’    (hÏ‡ : G.cardChromaticNumber = ğ”ª) :
    44â†’    âˆ€ (ğ”« : Cardinal.{u}), â„µâ‚€ â‰¤ ğ”« â†’ ğ”« < ğ”ª â†’
    45â†’    âˆƒ (W : Type u) (H : SimpleGraph W),
    46â†’      H.cardChromaticNumber = ğ”« âˆ§
    47â†’      âˆƒ f : W â†’ V, Function.Injective f âˆ§ âˆ€ a b, H.Adj a b â†’ G.Adj (f a) (f b) :=
    48â†’  sorry
    49â†’
    50â†’end
    51â†’

1â†’import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Basic
     2â†’import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Coloring
     3â†’import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Clique
     4â†’import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Acyclic
     5â†’import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Maps
     6â†’
     7â†’open SimpleGraph
     8â†’
     9â†’noncomputable section
    10â†’
    11â†’/-!
    12â†’# ErdÅ‘s Problem #738
    13â†’
    14â†’If $G$ has infinite chromatic number and is triangle-free (contains no $K_3$)
    15â†’then must $G$ contain every tree as an induced subgraph?
    16â†’
    17â†’A conjecture of GyÃ¡rfÃ¡s [Er81].
    18â†’
    19â†’https://www.erdosproblems.com/738
    20â†’-/
    21â†’
    22â†’/-- A graph has infinite chromatic number: it cannot be properly colored
    23â†’    with finitely many colors. -/
    24â†’def HasInfiniteChromaticNumber {V : Type*} (G : SimpleGraph V) : Prop :=
    25â†’  âˆ€ n : â„•, IsEmpty (G.Coloring (Fin n))
    26â†’
    27â†’/--
    28â†’ErdÅ‘s Problem #738 (GyÃ¡rfÃ¡s conjecture) [Er81]:
    29â†’
    30â†’If G is a graph with infinite chromatic number and G is triangle-free
    31â†’(contains no Kâ‚ƒ), then G contains every finite tree as an induced subgraph.
    32â†’-/
    33â†’theorem erdos_problem_738 {V : Type*} (G : SimpleGraph V)
    34â†’    (hchrom : HasInfiniteChromaticNumber G)
    35â†’    (htri : G.CliqueFree 3) :
    36â†’    âˆ€ (m : â„•) (T : SimpleGraph (Fin m)), T.IsTree â†’
    37â†’      Nonempty (T â†ªg G) :=
    38â†’  sorry
    39â†’
    40â†’end
    41â†’

content.text: Excellent! Now let me get a few more files, particularly ones dealing with diameter:

content.content:
1â†’import Mathlib.Analysis.InnerProductSpace.PiL2
     2â†’import Mathlib.Topology.MetricSpace.Bounded
     3â†’import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Basic
     4â†’import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
     5â†’
     6â†’open Metric
     7â†’
     8â†’/--
     9â†’All pairwise distances in a finite point set are separated by at least 1:
    10â†’for any two distinct unordered pairs {a, b} and {c, d} of points from A
    11â†’(where a â‰  b and c â‰  d), |dist(a, b) - dist(c, d)| â‰¥ 1.
    12â†’-/
    13â†’def AllPairwiseDistancesDifferByOne {X : Type*} [PseudoMetricSpace X]
    14â†’    (A : Finset X) : Prop :=
    15â†’  âˆ€ a b c d : X, a âˆˆ A â†’ b âˆˆ A â†’ c âˆˆ A â†’ d âˆˆ A â†’
    16â†’    a â‰  b â†’ c â‰  d â†’
    17â†’    (a â‰  c âˆ¨ b â‰  d) â†’ (a â‰  d âˆ¨ b â‰  c) â†’
    18â†’    |dist a b - dist c d| â‰¥ 1
    19â†’
    20â†’/--
    21â†’ErdÅ‘s Problem #670:
    22â†’Let A âŠ† â„^d be a set of n points such that all pairwise distances differ by
    23â†’at least 1. Is the diameter of A at least (1 + o(1))nÂ²?
    24â†’
    25â†’The lower bound of C(n,2) for the diameter is trivial. ErdÅ‘s [Er97f] proved
    26â†’the claim when d = 1.
    27â†’
    28â†’Formalized as: for every Îµ > 0, there exists N such that for all n â‰¥ N, for
    29â†’every dimension d and every set A of n points in â„^d with all pairwise
    30â†’distances differing by at least 1, the diameter of A is at least (1 - Îµ) Â· nÂ².
    31â†’-/
    32â†’theorem erdos_problem_670 :
    33â†’    âˆ€ Îµ : â„, 0 < Îµ â†’
    34â†’      âˆƒ N : â„•, âˆ€ n : â„•, N â‰¤ n â†’
    35â†’        âˆ€ d : â„•,
    36â†’          âˆ€ A : Finset (EuclideanSpace â„ (Fin d)),
    37â†’            A.card = n â†’
    38â†’            AllPairwiseDistancesDifferByOne A â†’
    39â†’            (1 - Îµ) * (n : â„) ^ 2 â‰¤
    40â†’              Metric.diam (A : Set (EuclideanSpace â„ (Fin d))) :=
    41â†’  sorry
    42â†’

1â†’import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Clique
     2â†’import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Diam
     3â†’import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Finite
     4â†’import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Connectivity.Connected
     5â†’import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
     6â†’import Mathlib.Data.Nat.Lattice
     7â†’
     8â†’open Classical SimpleGraph
     9â†’
    10â†’noncomputable section
    11â†’
    12â†’/-!
    13â†’# ErdÅ‘s Problem #619
    14â†’
    15â†’For a triangle-free graph $G$ let $h_r(G)$ be the smallest number of edges that
    16â†’need to be added to $G$ so that it has diameter $r$ (while preserving the property
    17â†’of being triangle-free).
    18â†’
    19â†’Is it true that there exists a constant $c > 0$ such that if $G$ is a connected
    20â†’graph on $n$ vertices then $h_4(G) < (1 - c)n$?
    21â†’
    22â†’A problem of ErdÅ‘s, GyÃ¡rfÃ¡s, and RuszinkÃ³ [EGR98] who proved that $h_3(G) \leq n$
    23â†’and $h_5(G) \leq (n-1)/2$ and there exist connected graphs $G$ on $n$ vertices with
    24â†’$h_3(G) \geq n - c$ for some constant $c > 0$.
    25â†’
    26â†’Tags: graph theory
    27â†’-/
    28â†’
    29â†’/-- `triangleFreeDiamCompletion r G` is the minimum number of edges that must be added
    30â†’    to a triangle-free graph `G` on `Fin n` so that the resulting supergraph has
    31â†’    diameter at most `r` and remains triangle-free. Returns 0 if no such completion
    32â†’    exists (the set is empty and sInf defaults to 0). -/
    33â†’noncomputable def triangleFreeDiamCompletion {n : â„•} (r : â„•) (G : SimpleGraph (Fin n)) : â„• :=
    34â†’  sInf {k : â„• | âˆƒ H : SimpleGraph (Fin n), G â‰¤ H âˆ§
    35â†’    H.CliqueFree 3 âˆ§
    36â†’    H.Connected âˆ§
    37â†’    H.diam â‰¤ r âˆ§
    38â†’    (H.edgeFinset \ G.edgeFinset).card = k}
    39â†’
    40â†’/--
    41â†’**ErdÅ‘s Problem #619** [EGR98][Er99]:
    42â†’
    43â†’For a triangle-free graph G, let hâ‚„(G) be the smallest number of edges that need to
    44â†’be added to G so that it has diameter at most 4 and is still triangle-free.
    45â†’
    46â†’Is it true that there exists a constant c > 0 such that for every connected
    47â†’triangle-free graph G on n vertices, hâ‚„(G) < (1 - c) Â· n?
    48â†’-/
    49â†’theorem erdos_problem_619 :
    50â†’    âˆƒ c : â„, c > 0 âˆ§ âˆƒ Nâ‚€ : â„•, âˆ€ n : â„•, n â‰¥ Nâ‚€ â†’
    51â†’    âˆ€ G : SimpleGraph (Fin n),
    52â†’      G.CliqueFree 3 â†’
    53â†’      G.Connected â†’
    54â†’      (triangleFreeDiamCompletion 4 G : â„) < (1 - c) * (n : â„) :=
    55â†’  sorry
    56â†’
    57â†’end
    58â†’

1â†’import Mathlib.Analysis.InnerProductSpace.PiL2
     2â†’import Mathlib.Data.Finset.Basic
     3â†’import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
     4â†’
     5â†’/--
     6â†’A finite set of points in â„Â² has "1-separated distances" if:
     7â†’1. All pairwise distances between distinct points are at least 1.
     8â†’2. Any two distinct pairwise distance values differ by at least 1.
     9â†’-/
    10â†’def HasSeparatedDistances (A : Finset (EuclideanSpace â„ (Fin 2))) : Prop :=
    11â†’  (âˆ€ p âˆˆ A, âˆ€ q âˆˆ A, p â‰  q â†’ dist p q â‰¥ 1) âˆ§
    12â†’  (âˆ€ pâ‚ âˆˆ A, âˆ€ qâ‚ âˆˆ A, âˆ€ pâ‚‚ âˆˆ A, âˆ€ qâ‚‚ âˆˆ A,
    13â†’    pâ‚ â‰  qâ‚ â†’ pâ‚‚ â‰  qâ‚‚ â†’ dist pâ‚ qâ‚ â‰  dist pâ‚‚ qâ‚‚ â†’
    14â†’    |dist pâ‚ qâ‚ - dist pâ‚‚ qâ‚‚| â‰¥ 1)
    15â†’
    16â†’/--
    17â†’The diameter of a finite set of points in â„Â²: the supremum of all pairwise distances.
    18â†’-/
    19â†’noncomputable def finiteDiameter (A : Finset (EuclideanSpace â„ (Fin 2))) : â„ :=
    20â†’  sSup {d : â„ | âˆƒ p âˆˆ A, âˆƒ q âˆˆ A, d = dist p q}
    21â†’
    22â†’/--
    23â†’ErdÅ‘s's conjecture (Problem #100):
    24â†’If A is a set of n â‰¥ 2 points in â„Â² such that all pairwise distances are at
    25â†’least 1 and any two distinct pairwise distances differ by at least 1, then the
    26â†’diameter of A is â‰« n. That is, there exists an absolute constant c > 0 such
    27â†’that diam(A) â‰¥ c * n for all such A.
    28â†’-/
    29â†’theorem erdos_problem_100 :
    30â†’  âˆƒ c : â„, c > 0 âˆ§
    31â†’  âˆ€ (A : Finset (EuclideanSpace â„ (Fin 2))),
    32â†’    1 < A.card â†’
    33â†’    HasSeparatedDistances A â†’
    34â†’    finiteDiameter A â‰¥ c * (A.card : â„) :=
    35â†’sorry
    36â†’

content.text:
Perfect! I've found excellent examples. Let me provide you with the results:

## Search Results: SimpleGraph Usage in ErdÅ‘s Conjectures

I found 149 files using SimpleGraph and related graph concepts in the conjectures directory. Here are 3 detailed examples:

### 1. **Conjecture 619 - Triangle-free Graph Diameter** (`/home/ryan/erdos/conjectures/619.lean`)

This file focuses on graph diameter and connectivity:

```lean
import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Clique
import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Diam
import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Finite
import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Connectivity.Connected
import Mathlib.Data.Real.Basic
import Mathlib.Data.Nat.Lattice

open Classical SimpleGraph

noncomputable section

/-!
# ErdÅ‘s Problem #619

For a triangle-free graph $G$ let $h_r(G)$ be the smallest number of edges that
need to be added to $G$ so that it has diameter $r$ (while preserving the property
of being triangle-free).

Is it true that there exists a constant $c > 0$ such that if $G$ is a connected
graph on $n$ vertices then $h_4(G) < (1 - c)n$?

A problem of ErdÅ‘s, GyÃ¡rfÃ¡s, and RuszinkÃ³ [EGR98] who proved that $h_3(G) \leq n$
and $h_5(G) \leq (n-1)/2$ and there exist connected graphs $G$ on $n$ vertices with
$h_3(G) \geq n - c$ for some constant $c > 0$.

Tags: graph theory
-/

/-- `triangleFreeDiamCompletion r G` is the minimum number of edges that must be added
    to a triangle-free graph `G` on `Fin n` so that the resulting supergraph has
    diameter at most `r` and remains triangle-free. Returns 0 if no such completion
    exists (the set is empty and sInf defaults to 0). -/
noncomputable def triangleFreeDiamCompletion {n : â„•} (r : â„•) (G : SimpleGraph (Fin n)) : â„• :=
  sInf {k : â„• | âˆƒ H : SimpleGraph (Fin n), G â‰¤ H âˆ§
    H.CliqueFree 3 âˆ§
    H.Connected âˆ§
    H.diam â‰¤ r âˆ§
    (H.edgeFinset \ G.edgeFinset).card = k}

/--
**ErdÅ‘s Problem #619** [EGR98][Er99]:

For a triangle-free graph G, let hâ‚„(G) be the smallest number of edges that need to
be added to G so that it has diameter at most 4 and is still triangle-free.

Is it true that there exists a constant c > 0 such that for every connected
triangle-free graph G on n vertices, hâ‚„(G) < (1 - c) Â· n?
-/
theorem erdos_problem_619 :
    âˆƒ c : â„, c > 0 âˆ§ âˆƒ Nâ‚€ : â„•, âˆ€ n : â„•, n â‰¥ Nâ‚€ â†’
    âˆ€ G : SimpleGraph (Fin n),
      G.CliqueFree 3 â†’
      G.Connected â†’
      (triangleFreeDiamCompletion 4 G : â„) < (1 - c) * (n : â„) :=
  sorry

end
```

### 2. **Conjecture 740 - Cardinal Chromatic Number** (`/home/ryan/erdos/conjectures/740.lean`)

This file demonstrates chromatic number and cycle properties in graphs:

```lean
import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Basic
import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Coloring
import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Walks.Basic
import Mathlib.SetTheory.Cardinal.Aleph

open SimpleGraph Cardinal

universe u

noncomputable section

/-!
# ErdÅ‘s Problem #740

Let ğ”ª be an infinite cardinal and G be a graph with chromatic number ğ”ª.
Let r â‰¥ 1. Must G contain a subgraph of chromatic number ğ”ª which does not
contain any odd cycle of length â‰¤ r?

A question of ErdÅ‘s and Hajnal [Er69b][Er71,p.100][Er81][Er95d].
RÃ¶dl proved this is true if ğ”ª = â„µâ‚€ and r = 3 (see [108] for the finitary
version).

More generally, ErdÅ‘s and Hajnal asked whether for every cardinal ğ”ª and
integer r, there exists f_r(ğ”ª) such that every graph with chromatic number
â‰¥ f_r(ğ”ª) contains a subgraph with chromatic number ğ”ª with no odd cycle
of length â‰¤ r.

https://www.erdosproblems.com/740
-/

/-- The cardinal chromatic number of a graph: the infimum of cardinals Îº
    for which G admits a proper Îº-coloring. -/
noncomputable def SimpleGraph.cardChromaticNumber {V : Type u}
    (G : SimpleGraph V) : Cardinal.{u} :=
  sInf {Îº : Cardinal.{u} | âˆƒ (Î± : Type u), #Î± = Îº âˆ§ Nonempty (G.Coloring Î±)}

/--
ErdÅ‘s Problem #740 [Er69b][Er71][Er81][Er95d]:

If G is a graph with infinite chromatic number ğ”ª, then for every r â‰¥ 1,
G contains a subgraph with chromatic number ğ”ª that has no odd cycle of
length â‰¤ r.

A question of ErdÅ‘s and Hajnal. RÃ¶dl proved the case ğ”ª = â„µâ‚€, r = 3.
-/
theorem erdos_problem_740 {V : Type u} (G : SimpleGraph V)
    (ğ”ª : Cardinal.{u}) (hğ”ª_inf : â„µâ‚€ â‰¤ ğ”ª)
    (hÏ‡ : G.cardChromaticNumber = ğ”ª) (r : â„•) (hr : 1 â‰¤ r) :
    âˆƒ (W : Type u) (H : SimpleGraph W),
      H.cardChromaticNumber = ğ”ª âˆ§
      (âˆƒ f : W â†’ V, Function.Injective f âˆ§ âˆ€ a b, H.Adj a b â†’ G.Adj (f a) (f b)) âˆ§
      (âˆ€ (w : W) (p : H.Walk w w), p.IsCycle â†’ Odd p.length â†’ r < p.length) :=
  sorry

end
```

### 3. **Conjecture 738 - Chromatic Number and Tree Induced Subgraphs** (`/home/ryan/erdos/conjectures/738.lean`)

This file explores infinite chromatic numbers and induced subgraphs:

```lean
import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Basic
import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Coloring
import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Clique
import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Acyclic
import Mathlib.Combinatorics.SimpleGraph.Maps

open SimpleGraph

noncomputable section

/-!
# ErdÅ‘s Problem #738

If $G$ has infinite chromatic number and is triangle-free (contains no $K_3$)
then must $G$ contain every tree as an induced subgraph?

A conjecture of GyÃ¡rfÃ¡s [Er81].

https://www.erdosproblems.com/738
-/

/-- A graph has infinite chromatic number: it cannot be properly colored
    with finitely many colors. -/
def HasInfiniteChromaticNumber {V : Type*} (G : SimpleGraph V) : Prop :=
  âˆ€ n : â„•, IsEmpty (G.Coloring (Fin n))

/--
ErdÅ‘s Problem #738 (GyÃ¡rfÃ¡s conjecture) [Er81]:

If G is a graph with infinite chromatic number and G is triangle-free
(contains no Kâ‚ƒ), then G contains every finite tree as an induced subgraph.
-/
theorem erdos_problem_738 {V : Type*} (G : SimpleGraph V)
    (hchrom : HasInfiniteChromaticNumber G)
    (htri : G.CliqueFree 3) :
    âˆ€ (m : â„•) (T : SimpleGraph (Fin m)), T.IsTree â†’
      Nonempty (T â†ªg G) :=
  sorry

end
```

## Summary

These three examples demonstrate:
- **Conjecture 619**: Uses `SimpleGraph.diam` for diameter calculations, `CliqueFree`, and `Connected` properties
- **Conjecture 740**: Uses `SimpleGraph.Coloring`, `SimpleGraph.Adj`, and `SimpleGraph.Walk` for chromatic number analysis
- **Conjecture 738**: Uses `SimpleGraph.CliqueFree` and induced subgraph embeddings

All three are formalized as unsolved theorems with `sorry` placeholders, representing open mathematical problems from the ErdÅ‘s problems collection.
